Aside from The Walking Dead, Broken Sword has always been an exception to that rule. The first two games featured great puzzles, snappy dialogue, and intriguing mysteries. Then along comes Broken Sword 5: The Serpents Curse. It does away with the horrendous transition to 3D and instead returns to gorgeous 2D backdrops. Back again is the clever dialogue and intriguing but not too obscure puzzles, and it's back one more time for another clever mystery. I really, really cannot reccoemend this game enough. reviewText:
I enjoyed Broken Sword 5. The game made me laugh. Thumbs up.

… Well, if you want a little more detail than that, fine, I guess I could try to expand upon why it won me over.

I first learned that the point & click game series “Broken Sword” existed because of my cell phone actually. I had a smart phone. I had no games on it that would hold my attention for more than 15 minutes or so. And, at the time, I had a three-hour flight. Dreading boredom, I browsed games until I found Broken Sword 1.  Then a month later I bought Broken Sword 2. By that time I become a casual fan of the series so of course I bought Broken Sword 5.

It took me a bit to understand WHY this point and click game stood out to me. It wasn’t exactly ground breaking. Each game had a mystery plot that had the characters adventuring to new locations and trying to solve a murder that revolves around historical artifacts and each game had puzzles that made you think outside the box. The art was great and the voice acting was wonderful. The plot was  humorous and filled with fun loving characters.

It was good on all these levels, but there was an additional something that just makes it more noticeable to me. I still have trouble putting my finger on it, but I can only described the feel as a serene level of calm pleasantness. Playing Broken Sword 5 (as well as the other broken sword games) was like picking up a favorite book again or going fishing with some buddies.

There was no feeling of urgency to complete the game, no over exotic melodrama, no underlying political messages, jarring scenes of violence, or crazy car chases. I didn’t play this game because everyone else was talking about it or because it was on the latest and greatest tech.

It was a  casual player’s dream. To play a game just so it can bring out a chuckle and a stress dissipating smile, during those times when a person only seems to have a half an hour a day or so to themselves.

reviewText: Wow, this game is basically perfect! It was fun, it was exciting, it was groovy! This will be a love fest of a review since, for me, everything was perfect. The game is gorgeous. Seriously, it is one gigantic screentshot, with the beautifully drawn characters and locations with a hint of 3D to make them three dimensional. The detail and the color in this game never drops, whether you are on the streets of London and Paris, or a dingy shop on the outskirts of town, or a dank and dark cave. This game is eye candy. The characters are top notch. George and Nico are in top form. We have a great cast of supporting characters as well as familiar faces from previous Broken Sword games...and for all of you who played Broken Sword 1, the goat is back! The actors, the script, and story all come together to create an experience that hails back to the original Broken Sword. The music that was composed for this is very cool. I found myself dancing in my seat to the cool 1970's jam sequences. Now for the mechanics side. The game is a true point and click, with no keyboard interference. Every action has an animation, so sometimes George and Nico have to watch a side character, or listen to a side conversation before being able to act. This can be a tad annoying, but it helps focus attention in the right place. There is a wonderful hint system so that way you don't have to get stumped and search a walkthrough while in game. This game was made with wanting players to have fun, not to get irritated over puzzles. I would say that if you have never played any of the Broken Sword games, this could be a good start, and then go back a play the first game in the series. Also, I would vouch to say that if you like a good detective/adventure story with religious conspiracy themes, this would be worth picking up, even if you don't usually play point-and-click adventures. If this is the last game in the Broken Sword series, I can't think it could have ended any better. I am very glad I played this, and know that there will be another playthrough in the future.

Back by nostalgic demand, this fifth installment of the franchise is something of a return to form, albeit one that is as guilty of replicating the faults of previous games as it at revisiting the strengths.

Abandoning the 3D worlds and returning to a 2D style, reminiscent of the first two installements, helps the game recapture the appealing artwork style that enhanced the atmosphere of those first two adventures. Not to mention the return of Barrington Pheloung on soundtrack duties. Meanwhile voice work is largely of a good quality, spear-headed by Rolf Saxon's now iconic performance as George Stobbart.

However, it's the story that really starts to let things down, with the plot taking some silly turns that push the player out of the narrative, keeping you at arm's length from really engaging with the events unfolding on screen. There are also a handful of puzzles that are frustrating in a way that stops you feeling like you're really experiencing the thoughtful adventure, meaning that you spend ages pursuing an idea that seems right, receive no confirmation that you're making any progress, and then feel lost, only to realise that you were right to begin with... and not in some sort of rewarding I'm a genius!" fashion

reviewText:
I'm a huge fan of the Broken Sword series.  George and Nico are second only to Guybrush and Elaine.  I tried not to mind too much when the series shifted to 3D and some action for the third and fourth installments because Revolution were clearly handling the games with care and love for the genre.  Still, I was thrilled when it became clear on Kickstarter that the fifth game would be 2D and action-free.

The artwork in the game is about the best of this style that I have ever seen in a game.  Scenes are beautiful and detailed (and that really helps when you have to notice a slightly pink spot on a sort of orange spot).  I had to resist taking screenshots because they would all be spoilers.

The game presents you with pretty standard environment, inventory, and dialog puzzles, but they all work pretty sensibly, even the decrypting puzzles late in the game.  I never got stuck due to some ridiculously obtuse puzzle structure.

The worst I can say about the game is that there are so many spots to interact with, so many comments to hear (although still less than in a typical Daedalic game, by comparison) that you can progress pretty slowly and it's possible to get bored.  Still, the story is well written with a typical Indiana Jones plus reluctant hero approach as in the other Broken Sword games.  I did find it to be slightly less boring than the fourth game (which is finally on Steam, by the way).  The religious aspect of the story focuses on a conspiracy-flavored long line of Gnostics protecting an artifact that could upset the balance of Jehovah and Lucifer, so you kind of know the story will take you around Europe and eventually to the Middle East.

So if you like the very best that standard point-and-click gameplay can offer, reasonable puzzles, and the best 2D artwork anywhere, this game is a must-play. Depending on your ability and your choice of pace, it's about a 12 hour game at least, possibly as much as 14 hours, longer than that other crowd-funded classic adventure game two-part installment that still isn't finished (ahem-cough-Broken-Age-cough).

reviewText:
I was really entertained by this game and had a few chuckles, but there were times, when I was probably too tired, that I felt it was really testing my patience and dragging it's feet to much. I completed the game in little less than 15 hours and despite cutting a few lines I had heard before during trial and error, I wasn't really in a rush.

Puzzle-solving Adventure games are always a little on the edge, because developers have to come up with new puzzles and find a way to balance them and incorporate them into the natural flow. Being an Old School Adventure player I found a lot of things to be quite intuitive and straightforward, but there were also a few very complicated puzzles and some that were too hard for me.

BS5 have added a gentle Hint system, that you can access whenever you feel lost, that nudges you in the right way with each option until it completely spoils you with the last option, but there were times when I found the spoilage to be just as cryptic as the problem itself. Even with the solution at hand I know there are puzzles I would never have guessed at all. There were times when it was hard to resist using the Hint system, but I really recommend not using it too much, because it is a rather short game and relying on hints too much dulls your mind to the point where you are almost completely dependent on them.

The game looks and sounds pretty nice in the Broken Sword 2D style and the resolution is pretty high too, but there are times when the generally nice and smooth, but sometimes too flat and bland graphics worked against the puzzle solving of the game, it simply doesn't support the needed attention to detail and there were times when I really wished there had been more controls than just the mouse to move parts of the game.

The one thing this game really required of me above all else was PATIENCE! I often found myself to be quite annoyed with the slow mechanics of the game. The slow movement of the characters, the repetitious nature of problem solving like the repetition of the same walk, talk, action and 3-4 mental notes that kept popping up in boxes like bubbles in a club soda was really straining my decreasing patience a lot. Phew.

I think the price of the game at $14.99 is a actually a bit too high, $9.99 would probably be too little, but I wouldn't have had any second thoughts about the worth of the game, because even though it's really a nice game the constant challenge of my patience really detracts a lot from my joy of the game, but I had a good time and in the end game there was a nice crazy turn of events and a romantic touch, that saved the day.

reviewText: For years now, as a series, it’s been pulling the nails back out of the adventure genre’s coffin, even when it misfired with titles like #4. The Serpent’s Curse is a successful rolling reboot in that it has taken on so much of what made the previous titles special, but is trying not to allow itself to be anchored to the past. New Broken Sword is good game, all adventure fans will enjoy it for sure (and it doesn't matter if this is your first or fifth game of the series). Characters are really fleshed out and every one of them has memorable personality unlike many other games. reviewText:
I'm finding it very hard to give this a recommendation, yet also feel rather bad for giving it the thumbs down.

It starts off as a great return to the old classics that were 1 and 2. The atmosphere is great, it's visually pleasing to look at and the voice acting is really well done. The puzzles are, at the start at least, well done and requires quite a bit of 'out of the box' thinking.
Old characters return, which is always nice, but some are just there to be there and be even more ridiculous than before.

And here comes the part... Later in the game, it doesn't just require the player to think outside the box, it actually gets down to, should I say, ridiculous puzzle solving. Trying not to spoil too much, I managed just fine on my own with the game, until there was a puzzle that just made absolutely no sense (to me) in any way. I thought that was fine, but then came another one and... Dare I say, even another one. Sure, not all puzzles are meant to be easy, but I found these to be a bit too over complicated, as if the developer thought they were clever.
Another gripe I have is that the voice acting of minor characters is off. A french person with an american accent or a rather obnoxious actor trying to imitate spanish. A pet peeve because it started off so well, then this happened.
When acting with a certain object, it sometimes doesn't even change to be interactive until the playe has looked at or interacted with something else. At the start, it's very minor, but later, it became a bugbear.
Then the typo's, there are so many in this game that it became bothersome.
Then there's the pacing. There's no quick walk or sprinting at all, nor double click to skip to next scene. Everything is very slowly paced and even the dialogue sometimes waits for several seconds to actually start. It drags the game out so long for no good reason.

And it's a shame, because the first half of the game is really damn good. After that, it starts to become a drag. I wanted to get on with the game, but it wouldn't let me. Throw in some obnoxious puzzles, have backwards logic, like not being able to interact with something when it made sense and that's pretty much Broken Sword 5.
I would commend it for being rather true to what it started out to be in the past though, but I simply can't recommend it like this. There are many point and click adventures out there that make more sense while having puzzles that work outside the box (Book of Unwritten Tales) that actually work.
If you're a fan of the series, it's a rather good addition to the series, but I'd suggest waiting until it's in the bargain bin.

Been a fan of point and clickers for as long as I can remember and been a long time fan for BS. When I saw it out for sale, I couldnt resist. We are greeted by pretty new graphics, yet familiar faces and voices with a story that seems promising.

If you are new to the series then I would suggest getting the triple pack of 123 together, however, if you are familiar with the series and want intrigue adventure and fun, well, so far, BS5 has the potential to 'deliver' but right now, it doesnt. Though we are promised a new chapter early in the new year, the first part of the game simply seems like a prolouge, does that mean after the next chapter they will start charging for the follow ons as DLC?

BS5 promises a lot but has delivered very little... so far... all it has done is set out a mountain of promises and I really hope it doesnt break them.

Right now I hope it gets better, I will always hold broken sword with eager eyes to 'reinvigorate' the genre again, but with games such as 'The Walking Dead' out there, there will be many people disappointed with this game.

reviewText:
I am a fan of the Broken Sword series ever since I was 10 and as such, I couldn't help feel very excited about the news of a fifth installment and of course I backed the kickstarter campaign. In this respect though, I am somewhat disappointed with the end product.

My first gripe is, of course, that this is actually not the end product - this is supposed to be just half of it. If you're new to the franchise DO NOT buy this game until you've played BS 1,2, and 3 (I don't believe 4 is in Steam) - it is much, much, much more value for money.

Of course, I read the update saying that there will be another episode in January (free for me, yay!), but when I saw that I have completed nearly half of the game, I thought that it was half of this episode - and it feels this way! this game is just so short, I was a bit dismayed even when I was thinking I did 1/4 of the story, not half of it! SPOILER ALLERT! BS5, as it is right now, is really just a murder investigation. I cannot help but compare it to the original Broken Sword, where the story just began as a murder investigation, but unfolded to be about much more! This time, it felt as if I was jumping down the rabbit whole... to find it painfuly shallow! I really hope that the second episode speeds up the pace and present and reveal more secrets for us to solve!

Finally, I really hope that there will be more locations in the second episode - in this one there were only five locations for us to explore. Again, a comparison to the original Broken Sword does not make the Serpent's Curse look too good. I can only assume - and hope - that we will be given more than just Paris, Spain and the promissed in the kickstarter campaing Middle Eastern/North African location (these are a must, of course!).

Finally, the reason I compare this game so much with the first one in the series is because the Serpent's Curse is made as mainly fan-service to the die-hard fans. 1 of the frequented locations in the game (that is, 20% of all of them) is an old one and a large portion of the characters are from the previous games. Nothing wrong with bringing old characters back, but the new ones are so few!

As a conclusion, you'll see that it says on Steam that I'm recommending this game. While this is true, it applies only to people who have played the previous installments - it is, after all, a Broken Sword game and the story looks promissing, so I am having high hopes for the second episode. But if you've never played any of the previous games - please, do, before bying this one! The story stands alone, you are not going to miss anything - however BS5 just does not provide as much value for money.

reviewText:
Another great game in the Broken Sword series. This one gets back into 2D style, which is actually a huge step forward because the free movement style of the previous two games didn't work so well.

Graphics is nice and colorful. Environments are attractive and detailed. All characters look great and their animations are smooth.

While the soundtrack doesn't seem so memorable as the ones in the first two games, it still is very good and only adds to the atmosphere. Voice acting is absolutely perfect, as always.

The story goes in the style of previous games. It includes all the things Broken Sword is known for - murder, mystery, conspiracy, supernatural elements and goats. The game's characters are well-written and every each of them feels special. You'll also meet some people from the past (previous games).

There's a wide range of puzzles. Even though most puzzles aren't very hard to figure out, there are some that are rather challenging.

Every point-and-click fan should get this game. And if you decide to give it a try, I recommend playing Broken Sword 1 and 2 first, so you can experience the original adventure and get to know the protagonists.

reviewText:
I was so happy that one of my favourite point and click franchises was getting a new game, 7 years after the last game was released. I was jumping with excitement. What did I think of it when it came out? It was good..... That's basically all I can say about it. I really wanted to say more about this because I was expecting more, especially after a hugely successful kickstarter campaign making more than double the original target. I loved all of the broken sword games, I even have a disagreement with how people treat the 4th game. But it just seems to be missing the charm the other games had, the same goes for BS4. Whereabouts does this game rank along with the broken sword games, it ranks 4th. It's better than 4 but not as good as 2,3 or 1.

My one gripe I have with this are the puzzles seem way too simple and straight forward. Same thing as the director's cut of the original. They dumb down the puzzles so that people with half a brain could do. You just need to do the basic adventure things in order to do the puzzles. It doesn't really do much to stand out from the crowd. They also have the hint system make a return from 1 and 2, but unlike them, the hint system seems unnecessary. Again because of the simple puzzles.

The artwork is beautiful, as usual for broken sword. But the artwork in this seems better than the other games, especially the dated graphics of 3 and 4. Movements seem crisp and smooth which is a huge improvement of the awkward movements of NPCs in 1 and 2.

Dialogue is basically the same as the previous games so not much to talk about there.

Characters are again your typical broken sword characters. So not much to talk about there.

I think a few of the critics are missing the point of this game as well as other point click games. They're saying that it's timeless. Any point and click game can be timeless as long as it's done right. Point and click games are similar to old Atari 2600 games and nes game. They're so simple by today's standards but if they're done correct they can leave an impact on the gaming community as a whole. Easy to make but hard to master.

I love the idea of resurrecting old franchises as it appealsto all sorts of gamers. Newer gamers grab it because it looks new and interesting and older gamers grab it for the nostalgia. That's why I just love the feeling of playing another Broken Sword game and it was a good experience. Now I just need to wait for the next Monkey Island.

I just managed to complete the game, and the direction the game was taking toward the end of the game left me mostly dissatisfied. I think that this is a fantastic puzzler, and a great U-turn back toward what makes (made?) the Broken Sword series so good back in the day. However, when coming toward the final act of part two (roughly 80% into the game) you are faced with an extremely taxing puzzle that slows the pacing of the game down to a crawl. Upon completing this puzzle you are then faced with a situation where your antagonist miraculously knows off-hand all the information that you just toiled away to figure out, from the remains of a person who (literally) took the secret information to his grave. This scenario had me so irate that I began to pay attention to the flaws in the game: the way that characters turn their entire morality upside-down with little effort, the lacklustre voice acting from the supporting cast, the crutch of returning characters from the first two games in the series that the game leaned upon the entire time, and finally the extremely anti-climactic ending that isn't without its fair helping of cheese.

I feel that Part one is fantastic: the puzzles are exciting and the pacing of the story is well maintained. I only felt aggrieved toward the end when the dialogue practically vomited out all the loose ends that needed to be resolved in Part 2 (back when this title was split) like a cat regurgitating hairballs. It was poor writing and it left a bad taste in my mouth. Part 2 felt very rushed in comparison; I'm not sure what deadline the team were under, but the story was leaping from location to location at an uncomfortable pace and the puzzles became less about solving riddles and using logic and more of the classic point-and-click trope of try combining all your items in your inventory and see what ♥♥♥♥ sticks this time".

Despite all that I will recommend this game to lovers of the point-and-click adventure genre. It has its great moments

reviewText:
Continuing the tradition of Broken Sword, this first of two episodes doesn't disappoint. It's as if time stood still and you're still in the 90s, only with 21st century technological advancements! All of the charm, wit, humor, storyline, voice acting, and attention to detail is still there!! Pretty remarkable because most devs ruin classic franchises like this. Rolf Saxon hasn't lost a single step (to the contrary, only gained a few), his voice acting is top notch with his signature delivery and clever comical inflections. Emma Tate's Nico is wonderful, the character is true to form and hasn't lost a bit of appeal.

While the story is excellent, compelling, and altogether engaging, the return to 2D is exactly what was needed to move the series further. You will notice unbelieveably fluid, life-like, and beautiful character animations. It's something I have never seen in any adventure game and I play a lot. So what you have in the end is a beautiful 2D game combined with animations forged in the 3D gaming world. Really slick.

I can't recommend this game enough.

Looking forward to Part 2!

reviewText:
The first Broken Sword and its first sequel remain among my favourite point-and-click adventure games. (Remember to check the Director's Cut versions of those games!) #3 and #4 changed the art style (to 3D) and lost some of the magic in the process, although those aren't bad games either. reviewText:
Excellent game, brilliant scenes, vivid characters, great aesthetic, decent expansion -- Highly recommended.

To those who have never played the Borken Sword series, don’t worry, you don’t need the other games, funnily enough I went back to play the older titles after finishing this game.

So Broken Sword 5 is initially set in France, almost like the western hipster version of what we all wish France now is, but sadly isn’t. There are truly gorgeous scenes in this game, I couldn’t believe just how beautiful it came out. Visually I can’t fault this title for anything. Everything from the character animations to the dialogue boxes, to the in game interactivity is executed fairly flawlessly.

Sound wise the music is beautiful, changes according and well composed. The voice acting is spot on and never feels off. The mixing is brilliant and the mastering feels very on point as well.

Gameplay wise I found myself involved in the game, I found the puzzle made sense, and the characters were really dear to me and believable. I found myself getting lost once or twice, but the guide put me right on track again, I never felt like I needed one next to me.

Without spoiling anything, I felt bad that this game didn’t get as much money as it should have. I really want to see another Borken Sword game, maybe with this exact engine. There was very little to take away from it, I only wish there was a little more. The expansion although it was interesting and unique, I wish it added a big city or town.

Overall 4/5, excellent game, well worth the money, buy it.

reviewText:
Pros
+ Very similiar style to first two Broken Sword games
+ Good 2D graphics (for the most part)
+ Cheap

Cons
- Story is stupid
- Character animation is poor and very limited
- Some/most characters come across as annoying
- The writing is amateur-ish


As a big fan of the first two Broken Sword games, I was excited to see the series return to its roots after the last few releases. At first, I wasn't disappointed; the graphical style was spot on, and Rolf Saxon was back voicing the main character, with a similar witty approach.

However, that's where the similarities ended. I started to notice a lack of variation in the character animation, and when interacting with objects, mimed with empty hands instead of holding them. The cut scenes were ok, but some of the 2D style backdrops made me feel motion sick as they 'moved' to create a sense of perspective in panning shots.

Though the voice actors put in a good performance (mostly), that can't overcome the poor quality, amateur-ish script. A lot of the dialogue was clunky, and any humour felt false and out of place. The overarching story started well, but by the end was just over-the-top stupidity. The ending felt like the writer had had enough and just stuck any old crap on the end just to finish the game. Details such as how the police acted were also badly written, as if the writer didn't have the first idea of what police officers actually do. Yes, those characters were supposed to be a bit silly, but it crossed the line into ludicrousness.

In short, the only thing that got me to the end of the game was my love for the original two games. Although that was clearly what the developers were going for, that is all they went for, not quality or originality, but a pastiche with many original characters stuck into the game just because they could.

reviewText:
It's a good old graphic point'n click adventure with all the things that made good old point'n click adventures as good as annoying. I wish there was a neutral button. That's what I'd hit. Since there isn't one, I have to go with the negative evil thing: The bad just outweights the good.

I want slow adventure games to succeed. I really, really do. I love stories. I love characters. I love puzzles. I love getting involved into fantasy stuff. I love... ermm.. slowness in games? The Serpent's Curse managed to drag me into nostalgia, I suppose. And it's very much like its predecessors, almost like a copy. Still, things just don't add up anymore nowadays. It's like the devolpers haven't learned anything since 2006. How long can you drag nostalgia out?


The good:

- It's fairly heavy on story. I'm not at the end yet but still wanna find out about those mysteries
- It has beautifully drawn background graphics


The bad:

- Oh god, the voice acting. Nothing feels natural. I tried three different audio languages and I'm still lost here. In German (1st language), it's like listening to 3rd-graders reciting a play. English audio has hilariously spoken accents everywhere, Even I could hear the fake, and that says something. Finally I tried French and... well scratch that, my French has somehow dissolved over the years. Hopefully you'll get luckier with your audio.

- Holy hell, the puzzles. I forgot how annoying these can be sometimes. You often know EXACTLY what you need to do: Talk to this guy, give him that. Repair the machine using X. But it's never that easy, isn't it? Things have to be complicated. THEY HAVE to be, because point'n click adventure game. Oh man. I'm writing this review from a point in the game where I definitely know that I have to drive a frigging seagull off a lamppost by honking a horn. Problem: I have about 0,5 seconds to make three things at once happen. Even with a guide at hand, I've tried seven times so far. This whole situation is horrible. I hate guides. I don't wanna use them. This game gives me no choice though. I don't wanna run around offering everyone a banana for five hours and hope it'll stick. So, there's that.


Conclusion: This game is heavily outdated and only a thing for hardcore nostalgists. or masochists. Or people who like to google for solutions. Or ones who like to do the same things over and over again.

reviewText:
I really wanted to love this game. I've followed the series and played them all. Fond memories from my youth and all that. But this game was just... painful.
My biggest complaint is pacing. It is slow. Painfully slow. Every single sequence takes SO long to complete because of the ridiculously slow movement speed (seriously, guys, a jog won't kill you) and the stilted, meandering dialogue.
The puzzles lack any of the clever ingenuity of the early games. In this game they're reduced to lucky combinations of items, or downright nonsensical logic. It's no surprise they incorporated a hint system, because so many of the puzzles make zero sense.
There are many more issues, visibility of important puzzle components, janky mechanics, a frustrating inventory system, poor dialogue, but I think the biggest is just, the lack of a strong plot.
The whole thing is poorly written, and totally cliche, downright stealing elements from earlier games and just rehashing them.
Despite my love for the series, I can't recommend this game. It's janky, slow, poorly developed, and lacks the charm that really helps you put up with the bad. The plot isn't compelling, and there's really no incentive to see it through.
I'm disappointed.

reviewText:
I will preface this review by saying that Broken Sword 2 was the first video game I ever played when I got my first PC about 17 years ago. It left a huge imprint on my gamer psyche and made me an avid fan of point and click adventures. After finishing The Smoking Mirror, I went to the original installment and my mind was blown - it was even better. The old games didn't have the best graphics in the modern sense, but their world felt rich, alive and intricate. Every character felt real, tangible and memorable. I never felt as though I was only playing a video game - it felt like an entire new world, with its own characters, stakeholders and conspiracies. Every location was a treat and seemed alive and genuine.

Sadly, not many of these things can be said for The Serpent's Curse. The game attempts to cater to the original fanbase by doing a lot of fan service, such as reintroducing certain characters and puzzles from the previous games, but it fails miserably at evoking the feelings of The Shadow of the Templars and The Smoking Mirror. The few locations that are introduced feel bland, static, unalive and uninteresting. The characters are even more boring and lifeless. The game attempts to buy cheap points by taking us to familiar locations such an art gallery in Paris and an old mansion in Spain, and this particular manipulation is obvious from the very beginning. The whole world of BS 5 feels static and fake. Sure the graphics are nice, but that's not enough to offset the constant feeling of emptiness and as though the game was rushed in order to maximize its profit margin. The ending is particularly bland and disappointing, and it's hard to imagine that such poor writing actually made it into the game.

Whether I recommend playing The Serpent's Curse or not depends on what you're looking for. If you want to relive the experience and memories of the old games, give this one a wide berth. If you're simply looking for a somewhat decent pont and click adventure, it might be worth a playthrough... but keep your expectations in check.

A worthy sequel to the broken sword series! Withold-school click&point mechanics as well as handdraw 2D-backgrounds, revolution games revives the spirit of the first two games. Murder in Paris, George and Nico and conspiracies this part of the series has it all.

Pros:
* Nice puzzle design, with some really challenging bits (Decoding an encrypted telegramms for instance)
* Lovely drawn background
* Exciting, fast-paced story (at least after it picks up speed in the second half of part 1)
* Funny characters, conversations and refferences to the old games

Cons:
* 3D Character-models and lazy animations. (There are severall glitches due the mix of 3D-models and 2D-Backgrounds)
* Magic doors - I just don't get it, either you don't use doors (or at least not normal doors that need human interaction) or you animate character to open the doors, but doors magically opening and closing themselves just looks lazy and broken at the same time.
* Lame voice acting, that seldom feels like conversations but like everyone needing to take a peek at their lines before responding.

Nevertheless it is worth its money and a must for true fans of the series.

reviewText:
I've been a big fan of the Broken Sword series but it seems the studio behind it have attributed its success to its Christian iconography and puzzles. Yes, the original is still considered a classic and I urge you to go play it now if you haven't already, but gamers loved it for its characters, mystery and charm, not for its overwinding historical lesson of the Templars. The Serpent's Curse is trying to simulate everything that made the first game a runaway success, down to bringing back the same characters, the same locations and the same jokes. Even a goat makes a comeback, for eff's sake.

The game is also too long fro its own good and about halfway-through, started getting dull and repetetive. Even the puzzles started becoming needlessly dreary and complicated.

Is this game better than the last two? Most definitely. Does it outshine the original? Not by a long shot. Is it a good adventure game for fans of the series and those just getting into it? Probably, and sadly, no. You will get some entertainment out of it, but it's too busy being stuck in the past and will never really launch for you to embrace it fully.

reviewText:
The whole game felt rushed to me, due to the obvious Kickstarter campaign pressure. The animations were extremely shoddy and lifeless, and looked terrible at 2560x1440... With a glaringly obvious line around each character's neck, being visible in most scenes (which I presume the models were designed to rotate around). Everything also seems optimised for 420p, with the hand drawn pre-rendered backgrounds looking far less sharp than the glaringly obvious 3D character models... Which don't really fit with the style of going back to the game's roots. The few 3D mashup cutscenes were also jarring, considering this new / old combination style.

Puzzle wise, everything you need is usually within your immediate environment and they require little to no thought. Some of the solutions are also pretty absurd, with the attempts at humor being a letdown this outing. I remember actually being challenged by the original games, which is sad. Also, did I mention the backtracking? Don't expect many new environments. The things you can't interact with on your first visit signify multiple visits to the same location.

All of the usual charm and the bones of an interesting story are all there, but I'd avoid this until you can get your hands on the full version, or at least at a Steam Sale discount. The price is far too high for this level of quality. Let's hope the second episode is an improvement.

5/10.

reviewText:
Full disclosure - I pledged $15 to Broken Sword 5 on Kickstarter for a copy of the game.

In the opening moments of Broken Sword 5, I was cast back to playing the original Broken Sword game back in the 90's. A peaceful afternoon in France is quickly transformed into a murder mystery... The story beats are classic Broken Sword fare; a crime is committed, there may have been a deeper motive behind this crime than is first apparent, and digging deeper begins to tug at the threads of a historical conspiracy.

At first glance the 3D models used for the characters draw more attention to themselves than their hand-drawn and animated sprite counterparts of old, but this passes quickly. The background art is bright and vibrant and characterful, reminiscent of the previous old games (1 and 2, in particular). Voice actor Rolf Saxon returns for George Stobbart (and let's face it, it wouldn't be George without the same voice!), although Nico's voice actor has sadly been replaced. I must admit, however, that the change for Nico is not particularly jarring, with the new voice fitting in alongside George's well and you'll quickly forget that her voice was ever any different.

I found the puzzles mostly satisfying, only getting stuck a few times over both episodes, and fortunately the game has a built in hints system that works really well. It's a tiered system, first offering a vague hint, then building as you ask for more info until it just gives you the complete solution. I feel this is the best possible system a point-and-click game can have in place, allowing you to still feel like you've solved the puzzle on the first few hints, and ultimately saves you alt-tabbing out of the game for a guide in the worst case scenario. I felt comfortable negotiating most of the puzzles myself, but a few tricky and obscure puzzles had me stuck until a few hints pointed me back onto the right path.

A must-play for Broken Sword fans, and a great point'n'click game for those new to the series too. A few in-jokes may be missed, but you'll still enjoy the ride.

But the voice acting is good, the story intriguing and it is definitely one of the better Broken Sword games.

reviewText:
An engaging, but short adventure. The Broken Sword games as a whole have been compelling and number five offers many  thrills, much humor  and suspense, albeit in a small package. A few more locales and characters to interact with would have made this installment better. The hand drawn illustrations are some of the best I have seen in a modern game, if not rather unexpected in the digital age. The dialogue is both funny and charismatic. The mystery of the murders, the Tabula Veritatis and the ancient connection to Jehovah and Lucifer are interesting and may appeal to members of gnostic and catholic faiths.

The ending is good, but brief. If George and Nico's outing had been shown, it would have been a satisfying finale. As the conclusion is, it leaves players wanting more, but also wishing the story had lasted longer.

All in all, Broken Sword 5 is a fine game, worthy of praise, but a little lacking in depth. What it offers is interesting, but if the game had had a little more depth, it could have been as notable as the first.

reviewText:
I give it 7.5 Kooch's out of 10.
It is a solid return for the series, bringing in homage to it's classic roots.
The game's plot format is familiar; George is a bystander and witness to a murder in Paris, team up with Nico Collard, learn that the murder is tied into a string of religious conspiracy that has been ongoing for centuries, goats, code deciphering, etc.
That said, the plot still has its own twist and turns you may or may not see coming. However, one of the first issues I have with the game is the voice-acting.

Broken Sword has always had interesting and entertaining voice-acting, and I believe it to be one of the most important aspects of a modern adventure games. This game features a lot of recurring characters making come-backs from the first game, yet they are missing the matching vocal chords. I can understand this, really. But the replacements voices fail to sound anything like the original incarnations, inluding dialect. I'm not sure if the developers meant to completely re-imagine many of the returning characters, but it seemed that way. Most of these are minor characters, who sometimes save the day for you. So you can look past it a bit, maybe. But Nico is a major character and sounds bored and uninspired in every single line.
George Stobbart is the same dude he's always been, and that is a positive thing. Rolf Saxon delivers the lines true with consistancy.

As far as the split episodes go, I found the first episode more entertaining than the second, but that's kind of what is expected to happen when you release half of your game first. The first epsiode had a decent pacing with mostly interesting puzzles. Some puzzles were a bit hard to conclude, and still lacked a bit of sense when revealing the answer with the appreciated and optional 'Hint System'. You can chalk that up to me being dumb, the game having questionable build up, or anything in between> Its probably safe to say it was me.
But in the second episode a lot of the puzzles were about deciphering code. Some are complex with take a while to solve, but eventually you might get wore out when you're deciphering another coded letter or word problem after just finishing a decipher puzzle after just finishing a decipher after just finishing.....
But it clears up by the end of the episode.
Which brings me to my last problem. The ending.
I didn't like it. The last few endgame puzzles you solve are arguably simpler than 75% of the game. The exchange between you and the enemy, the way it appears visually on screen, the terrible rendering of the cutscene (and all others for that matter), and the extremely dull conclusion leaves a horrifying taste in your mouth.

All in all, it's good to see Broken Sword back again, but I'm hoping the next entry is more lined up with funding and can come back with more finesse and polish in a lot of places.
